description: Physiology and anatomy of living neurons and neural networks; Brain organization; Elements of nonlinear dynamics, the driven pendulum as paradigm for complexity, synchronicity, bifurcation, self-organization and chaos; Iterative maps on the interval, period-doubling route to chaos, universality and the Feigenbaum constant, Lyapunov exponents, entropy and information; Geometric characterization of attractors; Fractals and the Mandelbrot set; Neuron dynamics: from Hudgkin-Huxley to integrate and fire, bifurcation neuron; Artificial neural networks and connectionist models, Hopfield (attractor-type) networks, energy functions, convergence theorems, storage capacity, associative memory, pattern classification, pattern completion and error correction, the Morita network; Stochastic networks, simulated annealing and the Boltzmann machine, solution of optimization problems, hardware implementations of neural networks; the problem of learning, algorithmic approaches: Perception learning, back-propagation, Kohonnen's self-organizing maps and other networks; Coupled-map lattices; Selected applications including financial markets.
name: NEURAL NETWRKS & APPLIC

values.comments: Physiology and anatomy of living neurons and neural networks; Brain organization; Elements of nonlinear dynamics, the driven pendulum as paradigm for complexity, synchronicity, bifurcation, self-organization and chaos; Iterative maps on the interval, period-doubling route to chaos, universality and the Feigenbaum constant, Lyapunov exponents, entropy and information; Geometric characterization of attractors; Fractals and the Mandelbrot set; Neuron dynamics: from Hudgkin-Huxley to integrate and fire, bifurcation neuron; Artificial neural networks and connectionist models, Hopfield (attractor-type) networks, energy functions, convergence theorems, storage capacity, associative memory, pattern classification, pattern completion and error correction, the Morita network; Stochastic networks, simulated annealing and the Boltzmann machine, solution of optimization problems, hardware implementations of neural networks; the problem of learning, algorithmic approaches: Perception learning, back-propagation, Kohonnen's self-organizing maps and other networks; Coupled-map lattices; Selected applications including financial markets.  Many students felt that class organization was poor, in that due dates, assignments, and upcoming exams were not posted on Blackboard as expected. Students generally felt that backgrounds in math and engineering were extremely beneficial and that class material was appropriately challenging.   Professor Farhat was described by one student as “the best I’ve ever seen.” Some students expressed annoyance that the professor postponed the midterm and projects to the last two weeks of class and did not give breaks during the three-hour classes, but he was respected as a teacher for his love of the subject.   The workload was low for the majority of the class until the last two weeks when the midterms and projects were due, at which time the class became very stressful for many students.
